results.definition: the act of someone who picks up or takes something
examples: the pickings were easy
clothing could be had for the taking

results.definition: carry out
examples: take action
take steps
take vengeance

results.definition: require (time or space)
examples: It took three hours to get to work this morning
This event occupied a very short time

results.definition: take somebody somewhere
examples: We lead him to our chief
can you take me to the main entrance?
He conducted us to the palace

results.definition: get into one's hands, take physically
examples: Take a cookie!
Can you take this bag, please

results.definition: take on a certain form, attribute, or aspect
examples: His voice took on a sad tone
The story took a new turn
he adopted an air of superiority
She assumed strange manners
The gods assume human or animal form in these fables

results.definition: interpret something in a certain way; convey a particular meaning or impression
examples: I read this address as a satire
How should I take this message?
You can't take credit for this!

results.definition: take something or somebody with oneself somewhere
examples: Bring me the box from the other room
Take these letters to the boss
This brings me to the main point

results.definition: take into one's possession
examples: We are taking an orphan from Romania
I'll take three salmon steaks

results.definition: travel or go by means of a certain kind of transportation, or a certain route
examples: He takes the bus to work
She takes Route 1 to Newark

results.definition: pick out, select, or choose from a number of alternatives
examples: Take any one of these cards
Choose a good husband for your daughter
She selected a pair of shoes from among the dozen the salesgirl had shown her

results.definition: receive willingly something given or offered
examples: The only girl who would have him was the miller's daughter
I won't have this dog in my house!
Please accept my present

results.definition: assume, as of positions or roles
examples: She took the job as director of development
he occupies the position of manager
the young prince will soon occupy the throne

results.definition: take into consideration for exemplifying purposes
examples: Take the case of China
Consider the following case

results.definition: require as useful, just, or proper
examples: It takes nerve to do what she did
success usually requires hard work
This job asks a lot of patience and skill
This position demands a lot of personal sacrifice
This dinner calls for a spectacular dessert
This intervention does not postulate a patient's consent

results.definition: experience or feel or submit to
examples: Take a test
Take the plunge

results.definition: make a film or photograph of something
examples: take a scene
shoot a movie

results.definition: remove something concrete, as by lifting, pushing, or taking off, or remove something abstract
examples: remove a threat
remove a wrapper
Remove the dirty dishes from the table
take the gun from your pocket
This machine withdraws heat from the environment

results.definition: serve oneself to, or consume regularly
examples: Have another bowl of chicken soup!
I don't take sugar in my coffee

results.definition: accept or undergo, often unwillingly
examples: We took a pay cut

results.definition: make use of or accept for some purpose
examples: take a risk
take an opportunity

results.definition: take by force
examples: Hitler took the Baltic Republics
The army took the fort on the hill

results.definition: occupy or take on
examples: He assumes the lotus position
She took her seat on the stage
We took our seats in the orchestra
She took up her position behind the tree
strike a pose

results.definition: admit into a group or community
examples: accept students for graduate study
We'll have to vote on whether or not to admit a new member

results.definition: ascertain or determine by measuring, computing or take a reading from a dial
examples: take a pulse
A reading was taken of the earth's tremors

results.definition: be a student of a certain subject
examples: She is reading for the bar exam

results.definition: take as an undesirable consequence of some event or state of affairs
examples: the accident claimed three lives
The hard work took its toll on her

results.definition: head into a specified direction
examples: The escaped convict took to the hills
We made for the mountains

results.definition: point or cause to go (blows, weapons, or objects such as photographic equipment) towards
examples: Please don't aim at your little brother!
He trained his gun on the burglar
Don't train your camera on the women
Take a swipe at one's opponent

results.definition: be seized or affected in a specified way
examples: take sick
be taken drunk

results.definition: have with oneself; have on one's person
examples: She always takes an umbrella
I always carry money
She packs a gun when she goes into the mountains

results.definition: engage for service under a term of contract
examples: We took an apartment on a quiet street
Let's rent a car
Shall we take a guide in Rome?

results.definition: receive or obtain regularly
examples: We take the Times every day

results.definition: buy, select
examples: I'll take a pound of that sausage

results.definition: to get into a position of having, e.g., safety, comfort
examples: take shelter from the storm

results.definition: have sex with; archaic use
examples: He had taken this woman when she was most vulnerable

results.definition: lay claim to; as of an idea
examples: She took credit for the whole idea

results.definition: be designed to hold or take
examples: This surface will not take the dye

results.definition: be capable of holding or containing
examples: This box won't take all the items
The flask holds one gallon

results.definition: develop a habit
examples: He took to visiting bars

results.definition: proceed along in a vehicle
examples: We drive the turnpike to work

results.definition: obtain by winning
examples: Winner takes all
He took first prize

results.definition: be stricken by an illness, fall victim to an illness
examples: He got AIDS
She came down with pneumonia
She took a chill

results.definition: very attractive; capturing interest
examples: a fetching new hairstyle
something inexpressibly taking in his manner
a winning personality
